did.unittitle: Wagner Free Institute of Science museum accession books

bioghist.p: Incorporated by William Wagner in 1855, the Wagner Free Institute is a natural history museum and educational institution in Philadelphia that is dedicated to providing free public education in the sciences. William Wagner originally offered free lectures and classes in his home and at Spring Garden Hall. He later constructed an Institute building, which opened to the public in 1865. Since 1891, the specimen collections have been displayed according to Darwinian principles of evolution, the organizational scheme selected by renowned biologist Joseph Leidy during his tenure as head of the Institute's scientific and educational programs in the late 19th century.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the Museum accession books of the Wagner Free Institute of Science, in four volumes: vol. 1 - 1885-1907 (331 p.); vol. 2 - 1908-1966 (165 p.) (5 entries added in 1989); vol. 3 - 1892-1905 (164 p.); and vol. 4 - 1946-1950 (20 p.). The itemized listings in these books include accession date, accession number, specimen name, locality, source, quantity, and price. Volume 3 lists the specimens in the Wagner Collection. Volume 4 was kept by Curator Henry B. Roberts, and contains the note "Material noted in this book upon receipt and later listed in catalog books by numbers after determination, decision, as to what to do with material, etc. 27 nov. 58." All volumes have notations made by Henry B. Roberts.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
